mapping module¶

class mapping.BarcodeMapper(seq_file, design_file_path, bc_names, preceders, posts, lengths, reverse_complement)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class to extract and map barcodes from DNA sequences in FASTQ or CSV files.

seq_file¶

Path to the input FASTQ or sequence file.

Type:

str

design_file_path¶

Path to the CSV file containing designed sequences.

Type:

str

bc_names¶

Names of barcodes to extract.

Type:

list of str

preceders¶

Preceding sequences used for barcode extraction.

Type:

list of str

posts¶

Following sequences used for barcode extraction.

Type:

list of str

lengths¶

Lengths of each barcode to extract.

Type:

list of int

reverse_complement¶

Whether to reverse complement sequences before mapping.

Type:

bool

seq_df¶

DataFrame storing sequences.

Type:

dask.DataFrame or None

mapped_df¶

DataFrame storing barcodes mapped to design file.

Type:

dask.DataFrame or None

Example

>>> mapper = BarcodeMapper(
...     seq_file="reads.fastq",
...     design_file_path="design.csv",
...     bc_names=["AD", "AD_BC", "RPTR_BC"],
...     preceders=["GGCTAGC", "CGCGCC", "CTCGAG"],
...     posts=["", "", ""],
...     lengths=[120, 11, 14]
...     reverse_complement=True
... )
>>> mapped_df = mapper.create_map()
static add_barcode(seq_df, bc_name, preceder, post, bc_length=120)[source]¶

Extracts a barcode from sequences between a preceding and following pattern.

Parameters:

  • seq_df (pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame) – DataFrame containing a ‘sequence’ column.

  • bc_name (str) – Name of the barcode to create.

  • preceder (str) – Sequence preceding the barcode.

  • post (str) – Sequence following the barcode.

  • bc_length (int, optional) – Maximum length of barcode to extract. Defaults to 120.

Returns:

Updated DataFrame with barcode and quality columns.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame

Example

>>> df = pd.DataFrame({"sequence": ["AAAXXXCCC", "AAAYYYCCC"]})
>>> BarcodeMapper.add_barcode(df, "AD", "AAA", "CCC", 3)
   sequence   AD  AD_qual
0  AAAXXXCCC  XXX     True
1  AAAYYYCCC  YYY     True
add_multiple_barcodes(seq_df)[source]¶

Extracts all defined barcodes from sequences in a DataFrame.

Parameters:

seq_df (pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame) – DataFrame containing sequences.

Returns:

Updated DataFrame with all barcodes added.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame

Example

>>> df = pd.DataFrame({"sequence": ["AAAXXXCCC", "AAAYYYCCC"]})
>>> mapper = BarcodeMapper(...initialize...)
>>> mapper.add_multiple_barcodes(df)
check_designed(map_df)[source]¶

Marks sequences as ‘Designed’ based on a provided design file.

Parameters:

map_df (dask.DataFrame) – DataFrame with an ‘AD’ column of sequences to check.

Returns:

DataFrame with an additional ‘Designed’ column (1 if in design file, else 0).

Return type:

dask.DataFrame

Example

>>> mapper = BarcodeMapper(...initialize...)
>>> df_checked = mapper.check_designed(mapper.seq_df)
create_map(should_shorten_seq_file=False)[source]¶

Processes the sequence file, extracts barcodes, and maps them to designed sequences.

Parameters:

should_shorten_seq_file (str or bool, optional) – If provided as a path, the sequence file is first shortened and saved to this path. Defaults to False.

Returns:

DataFrame with barcodes mapped to design file.

Return type:

dask.DataFrame

Example

>>> mapper = BarcodeMapper(...initialize...)
>>> mapped_df = mapper.create_map()
static reverse_complement_series(s: Series) → Series[source]¶

Returns the reverse complement of a pandas Series of DNA sequences.

Parameters:

s (pd.Series) – Series of DNA sequences.

Returns:

Series of reverse complemented sequences.

Return type:

pd.Series

Example

>>> s = pd.Series(["ATGC", "GATTACA"])
>>> BarcodeMapper.reverse_complement_series(s)
0       GCAT
1    TGTAATC
dtype: object
save_parquet(path)[source]¶

Saves the mapped barcode DataFrame to a Parquet file with a progress bar.

Parameters:

path (str) – Path to save the Parquet file.

Returns:

None

Example

>>> mapper = BarcodeMapper(...initialize...)
>>> mapper.create_map()
>>> mapper.save_parquet("mapped_barcodes.parquet")
shorten_seq_file(output_file)[source]¶

Extracts the DNA sequences (2nd line of every FASTQ record) using awk.

Parameters:

output_file (str) – Path to save the extracted sequences.

Returns:

None

Example

>>> mapper = BarcodeMapper(...initialize...)
>>> mapper.shorten_seq_file("short_reads.txt")
